questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic with symptoms resembling pellagra, including dermatitis, ataxia, and neuropsychiatric manifestations. Urine analysis indicates aminoaciduria. Considering the presentation and the urinary findings, this disorder is likely due to a mutation in which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. SLC6A19

 

Option D:

                                                              

  • This disorder is Hartnup’s disease. It is an AR disorder with defective absorption of aromatic amino acids from intestine as well as reabsorption from renal tubules →excretion of amino acids in urine
  • The transporter protein (B0AT1) is encoded by SLC6A19gene
  • Mutation of this gene results in deficiency of this protein either in intestine or renal tubules or both
  • 2 chemically close transcription factors such as ACE 2 in renal & intestinal tubules are required for expression of transporter protein (B0AT1)
  • The pellagra-like symptoms are due to the deficiency of niacin derived from tryptophan. The common manifestations are dermatitis and ataxia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. SLC5A18: This gene is not associated with the described clinical presentation or aminoaciduria related to Hartnup disease.

 

Option B. SLC1A1: While this gene is involved in amino acid transport, mutations in SLC1A1 are not typically linked to the symptoms described here.

 

Option C. SLC7A9: Mutations in this gene are associated with cystinuria, a different condition characterized by defective renal reabsorption of certain amino acids, leading to kidney stone formation, not the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra-like symptoms (dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia), along with aminoaciduria, suggests Hartnup disease, which is characterized by the defective absorption of neutral amino acids, including tryptophan. Hartnup disease is caused by mutations in the SLC6A19 gene, which encodes a transporter protein responsible for the absorption of neutral amino acids in the intestines and kidneys.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 308, 557

questions.text: A 22-year-old male avid marathon runner presents to the clinic with fatigue and mild disorientation after long training sessions. Laboratory tests indicate slightly elevated ammonia levels. Given the patient's high level of physical activity, the physician considers the main route of ammonia transport from his skeletal muscles to the liver for detoxification. What is the primary form in which ammonia is transported in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alanine

 

Option B:

 

  • Free ammonia is toxic to cells, especially to the brain, hence excess ammonia generated has to be converted to nontoxic form then transported to the liver to enter into the urea cycle.
  • Transport of Ammonia from most of the tissues including the brain: As Glutamine with the help of the enzyme Glutamine Synthetase.
  • Glutamine Synthetase: Ammonia formed in most tissues including the brain is trapped by Glutamate to form Glutamine known as first line trapping of ammonia, requires ATP.
  • Glutaminase: In the liver, glutaminase removes the ammonia from Glutamine, ammonia then enter into urea cycle in the liver
  • Transport of Ammonia from skeletal muscle: From Skeletal Muscle as Alanine

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glutamine: While glutamine is a significant carrier of ammonia, particularly in the brain and other tissues, in the context of intense physical activity, alanine plays a more direct role in transporting ammonia from muscles due to its involvement in the alanine-glucose cycle.

 

Option C. Both A and B: Although glutamine does play a role in ammonia transport, the primary form under conditions of intense physical activity, like marathon running, is alanine due to the rapid generation and need for detoxification of ammonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During intense physical activity, alanine serves as the primary transporter of ammonia from skeletal muscle to the liver for detoxification, via the alanine-glucose cycle


Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 203.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive palmoplantar, nose & pinna pigmentation. Urine sample collected for benedict's test changes to black in the supernatant and the test gives greenish brown precipitate. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alkaptonuria

 

Option B:

 

  • Alkaptonuria is an inborn error of metabolism resulting from homogentisic acid oxidase deficiency, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid (HA), an intermediate in the catabolism of tyrosine.
  • Manifestations include homogentisic aciduria (the urine contains elevated levels of HA, which is oxidized to a dark pigment on standing), arthritis, deposition of black pigment (ochronosis) in cartilage and collagenous tissue.
  • Dietary restriction of phenylalanine and tyrosine will be helpful.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Phenylketonuria: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase; C/F - mentally retardation, agitation, hyperactivity, tremors & convulsions due to interference of phenylalanine with neurotransmitter synthesis & hypopigmentation (inhibition of tyrosinase)

 

Option C. Tyrosinemia type-2: Deficiency of tyrosine transaminase; C/F -Mental retardation, painful corneal lesions, photophobia and keratosis of palmar surface with increased urinary excretion of tyrosine and tyramine.

 

Option D. Argininosuccinic aciduria: Deficiency of argininosuccinate lyase with hyperammonemia and elevated argininosuccinate in CSF and excretion in urine and friable tufted hair (trichorrhexis nodosa).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkaptonuria is a rare metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of homogentisic acid, leading to its oxidation and polymerization, particularly in connective tissues (a condition known as ochronosis), resulting in dark pigmentation. The urine turning black upon standing or after adding an alkalizing agent (in this case, noted during a Benedict's test) is a hallmark sign of this condition.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 304-305, Lippincott 7/e: P 274.

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her 2-month-old infant to the pediatric clinic, reporting that the baby's urine has a distinct cabbage-like odor. This unusual symptom prompts the pediatrician to consider metabolic disorders that could be associated with such an olfactory finding. Based on the described symptom, what is the most probable diagnosis for this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tyrosinemia type 1  

 

Option C:

 

  • Hepatorenal Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type I) is an autosomal recessive condition due to a deficiency of enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase.
  • Symptoms usually appear within the first 6 months of life which includes mild mental retardation, Cabbage like odour in urine, hypoglycemia liver failure and finally death occurs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Leucine catabolism defect: Incorrect, as defects in leucine metabolism typically lead to the odor of maple syrup in the urine, not cabbage.

 

Option B. Hawkinsinuria: Incorrect, as this very rare metabolic disorder does not typically present with cabbage odor urine.

 

Option D. Maple syrup urine disease: Incorrect, as the characteristic odor associated with this disorder is sweet or burnt sugar, resembling maple syrup, not cabbage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 304-307, DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 239,240

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents with a history of mild mental retardation, episodes of vomiting, lethargy, seizures, and hypertonia that were first noted during the initial week of life. Amino acid screening reveals elevated levels of leucine, isoleucine, and valine. Based on these findings, which enzyme is likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase

 

Option A:

            

  • Branched chain amino acids include Valine, leucine, and isoleucine.
  • Deficiency of the branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase results in maple syrup urine disease à accumulation of branched chain ketoacids in blood, urine, and tissues.
  • The urine has the maple syrup odor with development of metabolic acidosis. 
  • Early diagnosis is important to reduce the occurrence of irreversible mental retardation.
  • Treatment: Diet with limited amounts of these amino acids.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cystathionine synthase: Congenital homocystinuria, C/F-Mental retardation, Ectopia lentis, Thrombosis and Charlie Chaplin gait.

 

Option C. Ornithine transcarbamylase: The only urea cycle disorder with X-linked trait. C/F- Hyperammonaemia, elevated levels of ammonia are associated with high glutamine levels in CSF and blood in the affected child. Mothers also have hyperammonaemia and an aversion to high protein diet.

 

Option D. Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: Methylmalonic Aciduria. C/F- MR, ketosis, hypotonia, Blood-methyl malonic acid is elevated and in urine -methyl maIonic acid and ketone bodies are seen. Treatment –Vitamin B12.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The elevated levels of leucine, isoleucine, and valine indicate Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), which is caused by a deficiency in the branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase complex.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 309-311.

choices.text: A and R both are wrong
A is a wrong but R is a right statement
A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A
A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Cheesy odor in urine is mainly due to isovaleric acid excretion in urine, which is one of the intermediates formed during catabolism of leucine.

Reasoning (R): The defective enzyme in isovaleric acidemia is isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase which is a FAD+ dependent enzyme.

Which of the following is correct regarding the Assertion (A) and Reasoning (R)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A

 

Option D:

 

  • Metabolic disorders of branched-chain amino acid catabolism include hypervalinemia, maple syrup urine disease, intermittent branched-chain ketonuria, isovaleric acidemia, and methylmalonic aciduria.
  • In isovaleric acidemia, due to the defective function of enzyme isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase, the ingestion of protein-rich foods will elevate the diacylation product of isovaleryl-CoA, the isovalerate.
  • C/F: Vomiting, acidosis, coma, and excretion of isovalerate gives cheesy odour to urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isovaleric acidemia (FAD+ dependent enzyme) is a metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation and excretion of isovaleric acid in the urine, which leads to the distinctive "cheesy" odor. This condition is due to a deficiency in isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase, an enzyme crucial for the catabolism of leucine, an essential amino acid.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 309-312.

questions.text: Identify which of the following enzymes are considered hemoproteins.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both a & b

 

Option C:

 

Both nitric oxide synthase and tryptophan pyrrolase are examples of hemoproteins. Nitric oxide synthase uses heme to catalyze the production of nitric oxide, a critical signaling molecule. Tryptophan pyrrolase, involved in the catabolism of tryptophan, also contains heme as a key component of its active site, enabling its enzymatic function.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nitric oxide synthase: Correct, as it is a hemoprotein involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide.

 

Option B. Tryptophan pyrrolase: Also correct, as it is a hemoprotein participating in the metabolism of tryptophan.

 

Option D. None: Incorrect, as both listed enzymes are hemoproteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heme is present in:

 

  1. Hemoglobin
  2. Myoglobin
  3. Cytochromes
  4. Peroxidase
  5. Catalase
  6. Tryptophan pyrrolase
  7. Nitric oxide synthase

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 270.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids, is NOT considered an essential amino acid for adults?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serine

 

Option D:

 

Serine is a non-essential amino acid, meaning the human body can synthesize it and it does not need to be obtained exclusively through the diet. Serine plays roles in metabolism, muscle growth, and the immune system but can be produced by the body from other metabolites.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Histidine - Histidine is generally considered an essential amino acid, particularly in infants, as the body cannot synthesize it in sufficient amounts.

 

Option B: Isoleucine - Isoleucine is one of the branched-chain essential amino acids that must be obtained from the diet, important for muscle metabolism and immune function.

 

Option C: Arginine - Arginine is considered semi-essential or conditionally essential, meaning it is essential under certain conditions or life stages, such as infancy, pregnancy, or disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on Nutritional Requirements amino acids can be classified as

 

  1. Essential or indispensable
  2. Partially essential or Semi-essential
  3. Non-essential or Dispensable
  4. Conditionally essential amino acids

 

Essential or indispensable: Their carbon skeleton cannot be synthesized by our body and are to be taken in food for normal growth. Normal growth and optimal health will not occur, if one such amino acid is deficient in the diet.

 

E.g: Isoleucine (option B), Leucine, Threonine, Lysine, Methionine, Phenylalanine, Tryptophan, and Valine

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 27.

questions.text: Match the following metabolic disorders with their corresponding enzyme defect or deficiency:
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

Option B:

 

 

  • Non-ketotic Hyperglycinemia is characterized by a deficiency in the glycine cleavage system. This enzyme complex is crucial for the breakdown of glycine. A defect here leads to an accumulation of glycine in the body, particularly in the central nervous system, causing severe neurological symptoms.
  • Canavan disease is a rare inherited disorder that causes a buildup of N-acetylaspartic acid in the brain due to a deficiency in the enzyme N-aspartoacylase. This enzyme is crucial for the breakdown of N-acetylaspartic acid. Without it, the myelin sheath, which insulates nerve fibers, cannot be properly maintained.
  • Cystathioninuria is associated with a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionase, which is involved in the conversion of cystathionine to cysteine in the methionine metabolism pathway. A defect in this enzyme leads to an accumulation of cystathionine.
  • Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) is caused by a deficiency in the branched chain ketoacid decarboxylase enzyme complex. This enzyme is vital for the breakdown of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine). A deficiency results in the accumulation of these amino acids and their toxic by-products, giving the urine a sweet odor, reminiscent of maple syrup.  

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 211, 221.

questions.text: A pediatrician is evaluating a newborn for potential metabolic disorders due to some concerning symptoms. Given the suspicion of phenylketonuria (PKU) among other metabolic conditions, the pediatrician considers the most effective screening method to identify such diseases in their early stages. Which screening test is considered the gold standard for detecting PKU and similar metabolic disorders in newborns?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tandem Mass spectrometry  

 

Option D:

                                                       

  • Blood is obtained by heel-stick → applied to a filter-paper with four to six circles approximately 1 cm in diameter à allowed to dry and sent to a screening laboratory for further analysis.
  • Small circles of blood-soaked filter paper are punched out and metabolites are extracted with organic solvents.
  • Gold standard screening test for metabolic diseases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Western blot: Incorrect, as it's primarily used for protein analysis and not typically for newborn metabolic screening.

 

Option B. Electrophoresis: Incorrect, while it can separate molecules based on size and charge, it's not as comprehensive or specific for metabolic disorders as tandem mass spectrometry.

 

Option C. FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization): Incorrect, as FISH is mainly used for detecting chromosomal abnormalities and gene mapping, not for screening metabolic disorders like PKU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem Mass Spectrometry (MS/MS) is widely used in newborn screening programs for the detection of various metabolic disorders, including phenylketonuria (PKU). This method allows for the simultaneous screening of multiple disorders by analyzing patterns of specific metabolites in a small blood sample, usually obtained via heel prick in newborns. Its sensitivity and specificity make it an ideal choice for early detection.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e :p 427

questions.text: Which amino acid can be converted into an intermediate that plays a role in both the citric acid cycle and the urea cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aspartate

 

Option D:

 

  • Aspartate is a glucogenic amino acid, which carries NH4 + into the urea cycle.
  • Aspartate aminotransferase catalyzes the direct transamination of aspartate to oxaloacetate
  • Oxaloacetate may either be utilized in the citric acid cycle or undergo gluconeogenesis.
  • Argininosuccinate synthetase catalyzes the condensation of citrulline and aspartate to form argininosuccinate.
  • In this manner, one of the two nitrogens of urea is introduced into the urea cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Tyrosine - Tyrosine is primarily used for protein synthesis and the production of hormones and neurotransmitters.

 

Option B: Lysine - Lysine is an essential amino acid involved in protein synthesis but is not a direct precursor to citric acid or urea cycle intermediates.

 

Option C: Leucine - Leucine is a branched-chain amino acid used in protein synthesis and can be oxidized for energy but does not directly feed into the citric acid cycle or urea cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspartate can be converted to oxaloacetate, which is an intermediate in the citric acid cycle. Furthermore, aspartate is involved in the urea cycle, where it donates an amino group for the synthesis of arginine, which is then cleaved to form urea and ornithine. This connection highlights aspartate's role in both energy production and nitrogen disposal.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e p 203, 247.

questions.text: A newborn screening reveals elevated levels of branched-chain amino acids and their α-ketoacid derivatives, along with lactic acidosis. Which enzyme is likely affected by this disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

 

Option A:

 

  • The child has a mutation in the shared E3 submit of pyruvate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase and the branched chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase.
  • All the three reactions are oxidative decarboxylation reactions which utilize a three-component enzyme complex, designated as E1, E2 and E3.
  • The E1 subunit:  Binds thiamine pyrophosphate and catalyzes the decarboxylation reaction.
  • The E2 subunit: It is a trans acylase and involved in the oxidation-reduction part of the reaction.
  • The E3 subunit: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase is shared among all three enzymes and a mutation in this subunit will affect the activity of all three enzymes.
  • This subunit reduces NAD + using electrons obtained from reduced lipoic acid.
  • The problem is solved by recognising that lactic acidosis occurs when pyruvate dehydrogenase was defective.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: While part of the Krebs cycle, this enzyme is less directly impacted by the conditions described in the scenario.

 

Option C. Malate dehydrogenase: Also part of the Krebs cycle, but the scenario specifically suggests an issue more closely related to α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase due to the link with branched-chain amino acid metabolism.

 

Option D. Succinate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of both the Krebs cycle and the electron transport chain, but the described symptoms do not specifically implicate this enzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elevated branched-chain amino acids and their derivatives, along with lactic acidosis, suggest mitochondrial disruption, potentially due to Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), affecting the Krebs cycle. Excess NADH from MSUD inhibits key enzymes like α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, leading to lactic acidosis by diverting pyruvate to lactate.

 

Ref:  DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 208, 230, 431.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with flank pain and difficulty urinating. Kidney stone analysis reveals calcium oxalate composition. His parents have a history of similar issues. The accumulation of oxalate in this patient suggests a metabolic challenge with which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Glyoxylate

 

Option D:

 

  • The boy has primary oxaluria type I, an autosomal recessive trait, due to defect in a alanine glyoxylate aminotransferase which converts glyoxylate to glycine.
  • If this transaminase is defective, glyoxylate will accumulate and get oxidized to oxalate →in the presence of calcium will precipitate →form stones in the kidney.

 

 

  • The metabolic pathway for glycine being converted to glyoxylate is catalyzed by D-amino acid oxidase.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alanine: Incorrect, as alanine metabolism disruptions are not typically associated with oxalate stone formation.

 

Option B. Leucine: Incorrect, as leucine metabolism defects are more commonly linked to maple syrup urine disease and not directly to oxalate stone formation.

 

Option C. Lysine: Incorrect, as lysine's metabolic pathway does not directly result in oxalate accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcium oxalate stone formation can be linked to a disorder in glyoxylate metabolism. When glyoxylate is not properly metabolized, it can be converted to oxalate, which then combines with calcium to form calcium oxalate stones. This condition, often inherited, leads to recurrent stone formation and can be indicative of a primary hyperoxaluria type.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 213.

questions.text: Which enzyme is pivotal in the glycine cleavage system found in liver mitochondria?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Glycine Dehydrogenase

 

Option A:

 

  • Glycine undergoes oxidative deamination (reversal of glycine synthase) to form NH3, CO2 and the one-carbon unit methylene THFA.
  • It is the major catabolic route for glycine.
  • The glycine cleavage system is a multi-enzyme complex consisting of:
    • Glycine Dehydrogenase (decarboxylating) with pyridoxal phosphate
    • Lipoamide containing amino methyl transferase
    • Methylene THFA synthesizing enzyme
    • NAD+ dependent lipoamide dehydrogenase and is attached to a H-protein.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Glycine Transaminase: Incorrect, as this enzyme is involved in the transamination reactions, not the cleavage of glycine.

 

Option C. Glycine Carboxylase: Incorrect, as there is no enzyme specifically named glycine carboxylase involved in the glycine cleavage system.

 

Option D. Glycine Dehydratase: Incorrect, as this name does not correspond to the primary enzyme in the glycine cleavage system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The glycine cleavage system, a complex enzyme system found in liver mitochondria and other tissues, primarily involves Glycine Dehydrogenase (also known as P protein). This enzyme plays a crucial role in the breakdown of glycine, facilitating its conversion into smaller molecules that can be used in various metabolic pathways.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p302.

questions.text: In a university's biochemistry department, a group of students is preparing a presentation on rare metabolic disorders for an upcoming conference. One of the topics they are focusing on is Primary Oxaluria, specifically the less common type II variant. They delve into the underlying metabolic defect responsible for this condition. Which enzyme's malfunction is implicated in Primary Oxaluria type II?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  D-Glycerate Dehydrogenase

 

Option C:
 

Primary Hyperoxaluria Type I

 

  • The most common form of Primary hyperoxaluria due to a deficiency of the peroxisomal enzyme alanine-glyoxylate aminotransferase requires pyridoxine as its cofactor.
  • Protein targeting defect.
     

Primary Hyperoxaluria Type II (Glyceric Aciduria)

 

  • Due to a deficiency of D-glycerate dehydrogenase (glyoxylate reductase enzyme complex)


Secondary Hyperoxaluria

 

  • Due to Pyridoxine deficiency, after ingestion of ethylene glycol, high doses of vitamin C, after administration of the anesthetic agent methoxyflurane (which oxidizes directly to oxalic acid) and patients with inflammatory bowel disease or extensive resection of the bowel (enteric hyperoxaluria).

 

Nonketotic Hyperglycemia

 

  • Due to a defect in the Glycine Cleavage System.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glycine cleavage system: Incorrect, as defects in this system are associated with conditions like Non-ketotic Hyperglycinemia rather than Primary Oxaluria.

 

Option B. Alanine Glyoxylate Aminotransferase: Incorrect, this enzyme's deficiency is linked to Primary Oxaluria type I, not type II.

 

Option D. Excess Vitamin C: Incorrect, while excessive vitamin C can contribute to oxalate formation, it is not the underlying cause of Primary Oxaluria type II.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary Oxaluria type II is caused by a deficiency in D-Glycerate Dehydrogenase, an enzyme involved in the glyoxylate and hydroxypyruvate metabolism. This defect leads to the accumulation of oxalate and L-glycerate, contributing to the formation of kidney stones and other related symptoms.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 213.

questions.text: During a clinical review session focusing on metabolic disorders, a discussion emerges about the diagnostic markers associated with specific amino acid metabolic pathways. A resident recalls a case where elevated levels of FIGLU were noted in a patient's laboratory results, suggesting a disruption in a particular amino acid's metabolism. Which amino acids metabolic pathway is most likely associated with FIGLU as an intermediate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Histidine

 

Option B:

 

  • Histidine is first non-oxidatively deaminated by histidase to form urocanic acid (step 1) → then hydrated to imidazolone propionic acid (step 2) → then hydrolysed to formimino glutamic acid (FIGLU) (step 3) → cleaved into N5-formimino THFA and glutamic acid (step 4).
  • When folic acid is deficient, FIGLU is excreted in urine.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Valine: Incorrect, as valine metabolism does not involve FIGLU as an intermediate.

 

Option C. Methionine: Incorrect, methionine metabolism involves different intermediates and pathways, particularly those related to sulfur.

 

Option D. Arginine: Incorrect, arginine metabolism is primarily concerned with the urea cycle and does not involve FIGLU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Formiminoglutamic acid (FIGLU) is an intermediate in the metabolism of histidine. Its accumulation can be observed in conditions like folic acid deficiency, as folic acid is required for the conversion of FIGLU into another metabolite in the histidine degradation pathway.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 243.

choices.text: TMS is the best screening test to detect the metabolic disorders
TMS is less sensitive in screening for PKU than the bacterial inhibition tests
Blood obtained by heel-prick or cord blood is applied to a filter-paper
Has Capacity to screen multiple disorders with a single blood spot

questions.text: A 2-day-old infant is brought to the pediatric ward for newborn screening, as seen in the images provided. Regarding the screening test depicted in the pictures, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. TMS is less sensitive in screening for PKU than the bacterial inhibition tests

 

This statement is incorrect. Tandem Mass Spectrometry (TMS) is actually more sensitive and specific than bacterial inhibition tests (such as the Guthrie test) for detecting phenylketonuria (PKU).

 

Tandem Mass Spectrometry (TMS) has revolutionized newborn screening by providing higher sensitivity and specificity for detecting PKU and other metabolic disorders compared to older methods. TMS can directly measure phenylalanine levels and the phenylalanine-to-tyrosine ratio, which is more accurate for PKU detection than bacterial inhibition assays. The older bacterial inhibition tests had higher rates of false positives and were less precise in quantifying metabolite levels.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TMS is the best screening test to detect the metabolic disorders - CORRECT TMS is indeed considered the gold standard for newborn metabolic screening. It can simultaneously detect multiple metabolic disorders by analyzing amino acids, acylcarnitines, and other metabolites from a single blood spot with high sensitivity and specificity.

 

Option C. Blood obtained by heel-prick or cord blood is applied to a filter-paper - CORRECT Newborn screening typically involves collecting a few drops of blood from the infant's heel (heel-prick) or from the umbilical cord at birth. This blood is then applied to special filter paper (Guthrie cards) and allowed to dry before being sent to the laboratory for analysis.

 

Option D. Has capacity to screen multiple disorders with a single blood spot - CORRECT This is one of the major advantages of TMS. Unlike earlier screening methods that required separate tests for each disorder, TMS can simultaneously screen for dozens of metabolic disorders (including amino acid disorders, fatty acid oxidation disorders, and organic acidemias) using just a single blood spot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sensitivity of tandem MS-MS testing in screening for PKU is greater than the sensitivity of any bacterial inhibition or biochemical method for measuring blood phenylalanine levels. The power of new-born screening by tandem MS-MS is enormously enhanced by the ability to analyze several metabolites simultaneously in the same blood specimen. 

     

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 427,458.

questions.text: A child presenting with elevated levels of α-ketoacids of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) would likely benefit from supplementation with which vitamin?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Thiamine

 

Option D:

 

  • The child has maple syrup urine disease which is due to the defect in the branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase step that utilizes all three branched chain α-ketoacids as substrate.
  • This is an oxidative decarboxylation reaction, which requires the same five cofactors as pyruvate and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenases: thiamine, NAD+, FAD, lipoic acid and coenzyme A.
  • A subset of patients with this disorder has a mutation in the E1 subunit of the enzyme, which has reduced the affinity of the enzyme for vitamin B1.
  • Increasing the concentration of B1 therefore can be helpful in overcoming the effects of the mutation and allow the enzyme to exhibit sufficient activity to reduce the build-up of the toxic metabolites.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Niacin: Not directly involved in the function of the BCKAD complex or the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids.

 

Option B. Riboflavin: While riboflavin is a precursor to FAD, a cofactor for many enzymes, the direct connection to BCKAD complex activity in the context of MSUD is less significant than that of thiamine.

 

Option C. B12: Vitamin B12 is crucial for neurological health and the metabolism of certain amino acids, but it is not a cofactor for the BCKAD complex involved in MSUD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High levels of specific α-ketoacids indicate Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), stemming from a deficiency in an enzyme complex vital for breaking down certain amino acids. Thiamine supplementation can improve the enzyme's activity in some MSUD patients, potentially bettering clinical outcomes.

 

Ref:  DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 208, 230, 431.

choices.text: Glycine, arginine, histidine are the amino acids required for synthesis of creatinine
Creatinine is an anhydride product of guanidinoacetate
Creatinine is a product of enzymatic reaction
Levels of CK are elevated in myocardial infarction

questions.text: Which of the following statements about creatinine is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Levels of CK are elevated in myocardial infarction

 

Option D:

 

  • Normal serum creatinine level: 0.7 to 1.4 mg/dL and serum creatinine level: 0.2–0.4 mg/dL and Urine contains only negligible amounts of creatine in normal males.
  • In muscular dystrophies, the blood creatine and urinary creatinine are increased.
  • Creatinine level in blood is an indicator of renal function.
  • The enzyme CK is elevated in myocardial infarction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Glycine, arginine and methionine are the amino acids required for synthesis of creatinine.

 

Option B: The creatine phosphate is converted to its anhydride, creatinine

 

Option C: Creatinine is the product of Non-Enzymatic spontaneous reaction.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creatinine is a waste product derived from creatine, which is involved in energy storage in muscle cells. Creatine kinase (CK) is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of creatine and uses adenosine triphosphate (ATP) to create phosphocreatine (PCr) in muscle cells.

 

Elevated CK levels are indeed a marker of muscle damage, including myocardial infarction.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e p 211.

questions.text:
A neonatologist is assessing the nutritional content of various infant formulas to ensure they meet the requirements for normal growth and development of newborns. Essential amino acids, which must be sourced from the diet, are a critical component of these formulas. The neonatologist is considering an amino acid that, while beneficial, is not classified as essential and can be synthesized by the body.

 

Which amino acid mentioned is not essential to be present in infant formula for the normal growth and development of a newborn?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alanine

 

Option C:

 

  • Alanine is a non-essential amino acid which can be synthesized in our body even if it is not supplied by diet. All other amino acids are essential amino acids.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Tryptophan - Essential amino acid required from the diet for protein synthesis and other metabolic functions.

 

Option B: Lysine - An essential amino acid that must be obtained through diet for proper growth and tissue repair.

 

Option D: Leucine - An essential branched-chain amino acid important for protein synthesis and many other metabolic functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Essential Amino acids: Met, Arg, Trp, Thr, Val, Ile, Leu, Lys, Phe.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 282.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a transport protein?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Collagen

 

Option B:

 

Blood is a watery medium, hence lipids and lipid soluble substances can’t dissolve in the aqueous medium of blood. So these molecules are carried by specific carrier proteins known as Transport proteins.

 

Collagen is a structural protein and the main component of connective tissues in animals. It provides mechanical stability and strength to tissues, such as skin, tendons, bones, and cartilage, rather than functioning as a transport protein in the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Transferrin - Transferrin is a transport protein that binds and carries iron in the bloodstream.

 

Option C: Ceruloplasmin - Ceruloplasmin is a protein that transports copper in the blood and also has enzymatic activity.

 

Option D: Hemopexin - Hemopexin is a transport protein that binds free heme in the bloodstream, preventing oxidative damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PLASMA PROTEINS IN TRANSPORT FUNCTION

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 672.

questions.text: Immunoglobulins are classified as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycoproteins

 

Option B:

 

Immunoglobulins, or antibodies, are glycoproteins. They consist of protein chains (heavy and light chains) and have carbohydrate moieties attached to them, which contribute to their stability and functionality in the immune response.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Proteins - While immunoglobulins are proteins, this term alone does not fully capture their nature as they also contain carbohydrate groups.

 

Option C: Proteoglycans - These are mainly found in the extracellular matrix and consist of a core protein with one or more covalently attached glycosaminoglycan (GAG) chains, which is different from the structure of immunoglobulins.

 

Option D: Glycosides - These are molecules in which a sugar is bound to a non-carbohydrate moiety; this term does not describe the nature of immunoglobulins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biologically Important Glycoproteins

 

  • Plasma proteins (except albumin)
  • Blood group substances
  • Hormones (HCG, TSH, LH, FSHQ)
  • Enzyme-Alkaline Phosphatase
  • Structural Protein-Collagen
  • Transport Proteins-Ceruloplasmin, Transferrin.    

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 569.

questions.text: Is the statement "Serotonin is a neurotransmitter" true or false?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) True

 

Option A:

 

Explanation:

 

Serotonin is indeed a neurotransmitter. It is a monoamine that is widely found in the brain and the rest of the body, where it plays a role in regulating mood, appetite, and sleep, among other functions. Serotonin is known for contributing to feelings of well-being and happiness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amino Acid Derivatives as Neurotransmitters

 

  • Dopamine
  • Epinephrine
  • Norepinephrine
  • Serotonin
  • Gamma Amino Butyric Acid (GABA)

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 240

choices.text: Conversion of glycine to serine requires folic acid and B6
Ornithine decarboxylase is the rate limiting step of polyamine synthesis
The transport of one molecule of amino acid and regeneration of GSH requires 2 ATPs in Meister’s Cycle

questions.text: Identify which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The transport of one molecule of amino acid and regeneration of GSH requires 2 ATPs in Meister’s Cycle

 

Option C:

 

Meister Cycle (Gamma Glutamyl Cycle):

 

  • It aids in the absorption of neutral amino acids in intestines, kidney tubules and brain.
  • Glutathione plays a major role, which is a tripeptide (GSH) (gamma-glutamyl-cysteinyl glycine).
  • It reacts with the amino acid to form gamma-glutamyl amino acid, catalyzed by gamma-glutamyl transferase. Glutamyl amino acid is cleaved to free amino acid.
  • The net result is the transfer of an amino acid across the membrane.
  • Thus, the transport of one molecule of amino acid and regeneration of GSH requires 3 molecules of ATP.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glycine is converted to Serine by Serine Hydroxymethyl Transferase.

 

Coenzymes required are Folic acid and Pyridoxal Phosphate.

 

 

Option B. Polyamines are organic compounds having multiple amino groups. They are:

 

  • Putrescine derived from decarboxylation of Ornithine
  • Spermidine derived from Ornithine and Methionine
  • Spermine derived from Ornithine and Methionine

 

 

Steps of Polyamine synthesis

 

  • Ornithine is decarboxylated to form putrescine, by the enzyme ornithine decarboxylase, which is the rate limiting step of polyamine synthesis.
  • S-adenosyl Methionine is decarboxylated to form Decarboxylated SAM.
  • Decarboxylated SAM donates 3 carbon atoms and 1 α-amino group to putrescine to form Spermidine.
  • Decarboxylated SAM donates 3 carbon atoms and 1 α-amino group to Spermidine to form Spermine.

 

Option D. Amino acid that does not undergo Transamination

 

  1. Proline
  2. Hydroxyproline
  3. Threonine
  4. Lysine

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meister Cycle, where 3 ATPs needed for transporting one amino acid molecule and regenerating GSH, crucial in absorbing neutral amino acids.

questions.text: In managing a patient with Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), dietary restrictions are crucial. Among the following amino acids, which one does NOT need to be restricted in the diet for a patient with MSUD?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Methionine

 

Option A:

 

  • Branched chain amino acids include Valine, leucine and isoleucine.
  • Deficiency of the branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase results in maple syrup urine disease → accumulation of branched chain ketoacids in blood, urine, and tissues.
  • The urine has the maple syrup odour with development of metabolic acidosis. 
  • Early diagnosis is important to reduce the occurrence of irreversible mental retardation.
  • Treatment: Diet with limited amounts of these amino acids.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Valine: As a BCAA, valine needs to be restricted in the diet of MSUD patients.

 

Option C. Leucine: Leucine accumulation is particularly toxic in MSUD, necessitating dietary restriction.

 

Option D. Isoleucine: Another BCAA that needs to be limited in the diet of patients with MSUD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) is characterized by a deficiency in the branched-chain α-keto acid dehydrogenase complex, leading to the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) and their corresponding keto acids in the blood. The primary amino acids affected are leucine, isoleucine, and valine.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 230.

questions.text:
A dietician is explaining the concept of ketogenic and glucogenic amino acids to a group of medical students. These terms refer to the fate of the amino acids during metabolism, specifically whether they are converted to ketone bodies or glucose. The dietician asks the group to identify which amino acid listed is not solely ketogenic.

 

Ketogenic amino acids are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Histidine

 

Option D:

 

Histidine is not a ketogenic amino acid. It is primarily glucogenic, meaning its catabolism can contribute to gluconeogenesis, the process of generating glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Leucine - Leucine is strictly a ketogenic amino acid, meaning it can be broken down into acetyl-CoA and can lead to ketone body production.

 

Option B: Lysine - Lysine is also strictly ketogenic.

 

Option C: Tryptophan - Tryptophan is both ketogenic and glucogenic; it can lead to the production of both glucose and ketone bodies, so it is not solely ketogenic.

 

  • Leucine and Lysine → Pure ketogenic
  • Tryptophan → Glucogenic and ketogenic
  • Histidine → Pure glucogenic

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 27.
